messageBody:
Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:

>On 2/13/07, Michael Feathers <mfeathers@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>That's a neat name for a presentation. I had to cancel my
>presentation at SDWest unfortunately (I'll be speaking at QCon at that
>time), so I'll miss it, but I hope I'll get to attend at some point.
>
>
Yes, the name is a take off from a cool book by a guy named Nathaniel
Borenstein.

>I am currently writing a book and this encapsulation/testing tension
>has a big section dedicated to it. Even now, I still find myself
>having to do some convincing whenever I try to tell people that it's
>okay to remove "final" or make a private method "package protected" if
>it means that it will receive more testing.
>
>I think the pendulum will swing back eventually and that we will find
>a happy medium between the two goals.
>
>
I suspect it might, but part of me feels that the access protection
mechanisms in languages are justly poorly suited for what we want to do
now. I think one problem, though, is that it much of the advice on
protection that we hear comes from framework and API developers.
Frameworks and APIs are great, but I'm convinced that many of the rules
are different for run of the mill application code. Not everything is an
API.

Good luck on the book. Can you say what the topic is?

Michael Feathers
